post.body: Hello ZeroMe!
bah, why did i have to re-register here just now?

Even if i'm not big fan of new year concept, there's still one thing i really wanted to do "this year": migrate away from the old rotten centralized web into something better, or, at the very least, start such migration.

However, since i'm constantly postponing any efforts in this direction, the only thing i can actually get done before 2018 unleashes on us is start cross-posting into ZeroMe.

So, here it is.

###How vulnerabilities can improve performance

While some are complaining that patch for recent cpu vulnerability slows down their computers, the only thing i noticed is that my performance seems to increase. With more JS disabled and less browser uptime i have more free ram available and am less distracted by interwebs[.](https://caryoscelus.github.io/misc/2018/01/08/vulnerabilities.html)

After spending years of my youth on contemplating immortality, i came to a simple conclusion: for any *meaningful* definition of immortality that is worth achieving, it is impossible to *achieve* immortality. In other words, if definition of immortality has something in common with common sense understanding of the word *and* it looks like a desirable state, every entity either *is inherently immortal* or *will never be*.

The funny thing is, people tend to perceive word "freedom" as universally positive even if they don't really want freedom. To support their view they'll create convenient formulas: whatever they are comfortable with is "freedom" and whatever they don't like is "crime" (and thus, implicitly, not "freedom", despite these words being unrelated). But of course, such "convenience" leads to confusion, frustration and useless arguments, because (surprisingly) different people *actually have different and quite often conflicting* desires and strategies.

The hypocrisy of the common opinions on freedom also makes for an easy target of no less hypocritical criticism. "Enemy of my enemy is my friend", "whoever criticizes falsehood must be saying truth". And then people are wondering what went wrong.

I finally had a chance to listen to Kimiko Ishizaka's recording of Bach's Kunst der Fuge tonight. While i can't say much about its content rather than it being a great performance of great music, it is remarkable as being officially free/libre: it's published into public domain / covered by CC0 "unlicense". And that is still regrettably uncommon in the world of "classical music".

You can download it [here](https://music.kimiko-piano.com/album/j-s-bach-the-art-of-the-fugue-kunst-der-fuge-bwv-1080). Obviously it's a bit of an unfriendly site (e.g. you have to click pay even if you want to download it without paying, for which you can just set 0 price), but i think that could be forgiven all things considered. ..Now instead of

```
data Id {A : Set} (x : A) : A → Set where
  refl : Id x x
```

we can write

```
Id : {A : Set} → A → A → Set
Id {A} x y = W (A × A) (record
  { S = A
  ; P = λ a → ⊥
  ; outC = λ a → a , a
  ; inC = λ s p → ⊥-elim p
  }) (x , y)

refl : {A : Set} {x : A} → Id x x
refl {x = x} = con (x , λ p → ⊥-elim p)
```

It may seem as though the most important part of translating is understanding original meaning. Depending on source material, your knowledge of source and target languages, that could be far from reality. Canonical example is poetry translation where some translators might not even know original language and instead use raw (unpoetic) translation (not sure what's the proper term) and then turn it into poetry

Another thing is that translation might require better target language knowledge then doing original writing in it. When you do originals, you're free to choose style, grammar, words as you wish; translation doesn't give you that freedom. This is similar to playing your own music vs performing whatever is given to you: in former case you can work around your weakness, in latter you have to be prepared for anything

At its core, 0net is a distributed database + web api to read and write that db. Distributed, database and api levels all work, but have well known issues. Instead of addressing these individually, how about we look at the big picture and set priorities first?
  
Security, privacy, anonymity, efficiency, user control, ease of use and of site development, ability to create powerful apps all seem reasonable goals.
  
Typically, though, some of these goals are sacrificed for the sake of others. In particular, "power" in web, typically implemented via js and its apis, is a source of unwanted tracking and plain malicious code; privacy-protecting tools typically work by cutting down browser features. But does it really have to be that way? Shouldn't it be possible to build a rich application and prove it only does what it is supposed to (and thus isn't malicious) at the same time? Better yet, get that proof for free?

(continuing from [here](?Post/1White24UrrwQrD86o6Vrc1apgZ1x1o51/13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE/1564383413))

To solve tracking problem it should be enough to track all outgoing data. This sounds like a complicated, if not impossible, task. But only as long as we allow user-submitted code to do anything, if we treat it as a compiled blob. If we treat code as pure expressions (*code is data*), we can see what they evaluate to, which variables are in the formula (side note: implemented in most straightforward way, the system would allow false positives, e.g. if code author writes `current_time * 0`, the system might consider that `current_time` is used in calculation; but nobody should need such code and even if they somehow do, there can be a way to account for that too). As such, we can notify user exactly which data is collected (for example: text in field `message` and timestamp of clicking `post` button can be collected on message board); if user is curious, they can look what processing is done with that data, but for most low-interactive sites that shouldn't even be necessary. More complex apps, such as games (especially realtime ones), would need more thorough inspection, but even then those are supposed to collect your actions anyway (and passive fingerprinting info such as screen resolution can still be preserved).

There is one reason why writing one long track is easier than few short ones that add up to the same length: you can keep reusing same material (with variations, perhaps).
  
But there are more reasons why it's harder: if you want to get "full picture" of the song, listening takes more time; if you at all care about consistency, it's harder to preserve without sounding boring; even if it's not as monotonic to bore listeners, constant relistening may still bore you..

@Moor: it's really hard to track changes in thinking processes. I think i've noticed i don't really think in any language after i was learning lojban, but directly it was a result of introspection, so i can't say whether it was influenced by lojban in any way or not. Otherwise, lojban has capabilities to express thoughts in ways closer to how they appear, at least in terms of grammar; that might influence thinking processes, but i've never got to the point where i could actually construct complex construct on the fly. At best, i could think "what are the particles used in that construct?", then look them up and then make sentence; the great thing is, of course, that in lojban desired constructs exist more often than in natlangs. So one aspect of my thinking definitely changed: i became less forgiving to clumsiness of natlangs' grammar ^_^
  
Now for the bad things. The language itself is a little bit heavy; simple constructs are very simple, but when you want more complex grammar, the amount of particles can grow fast (one of the reasons for this is "monoparsing" and related to it lack of intonation based punctuation; "punctuation" in lojban is just words). I can't be certain of this due to lack of fluency, but it seems that some of the decisions might have been less than optimal. Another famous caveat is that for fine-grained concepts you either have long barely pronounceable words, or arbitrarily chosen words which you have to learn separately (like in any natlang; one of lojban's initial features was that if you learn ~2k root-words + particles and grammar, that's basically it)
  
But perhaps more disheartening for me were the community issues. Many people were creating new constructs in lojban, or alter how things work; some of these changes were adopted by majority, some weren't; but at some point the difference in dialects and ambitions of people to call their dialect "true lojban" led to some "heavy disputes". I might even be better off recommending ["zantufa"](https://mw.lojban.org/papri/zantufa), although i don't quite remember what were grammatical differences exactly
  
My final conclusion that it might be better to create a new language, taking experience of lojban and possibly other conlangs (ithkuil seems like another great language, but whereas learning lojban is easier than natlangs (barring lexical similarity), ithkuil might actually be harder), but then, of course, i never went far

(continuing from [1](?Post/1White24UrrwQrD86o6Vrc1apgZ1x1o51/13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE/1564383413) [2](?Post/1White24UrrwQrD86o6Vrc1apgZ1x1o51/13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE/1564423815))

API should be friendly and flexible, all data should be accessible to any app as long as user allows it. The easiest solution: do not mix&match fs and dbs, do not split db into multiple ones. This simplifies storage on one hand, but on the other, it poses some challenges in terms of organizing data flexibly. This can be solved either by allowing custom tables (inside one db) or by having universal schema extendible via tags. First approach simplifies advanced schemas, while second one simplifies things like search.
  
Both inter-node communication and API are probably to be based on db-access commands (i.e. create/modify/delete row(s)), with some hints to user as to why certain permissions are required. User should be able to give these permissions individually, or even using some (possibly complex) criteria (e.g. only allow certain app posting into certain "site", which by the way becomes ephemeral concept, but more on that later)

One question can arise from this: can all this coexist with current fs/db system? The answer is, of course, yes. Adopting existing data might be not the most pleasant thing, but it shouldn't be impossible. A conversion utility from signed `content.json` can be made, which, if enabled, would be alternative way to prove ownership of data. It would, of course require "too much" permissions, but 1) they will be "local" and 2) history logging should be available anyway

A note on using flashcards / spaced repetition: while it's possible to remember random info (e.g. words of a language which you don't use), it is more effective to first structure info you want to remember, make associations, etc. Multimedia cards (e.g. with pictures) may partially solve this, but they don't add much to the problem of differentiation between similar cards (words, characters, what have you). You'll have to put those in context, either by using what you learn or by creating some artificial contexts (back in the day when i was learning hiragana, i've made some [mnemonic rules](/1MCoA8rQHhwu4LY2t2aabqcGSRqrL8uf2X/?/_posts/2018-04-04-guide-to-hiragana.md) and it worked pretty well even without flashcards)

> Vielleicht wird man heute noch verstehen, daß es in jener Zeit als erbrechen gegolten hat, wenn eine Frau bei Sport oder Spiel eine Hose angelegt hätte. Aber wie die hysterische Prüderie begreiflich macht, daß eine Dame das Wort ›Hose‹ damals überhaupt nicht über die Lippen bringen durfte? **Sie müssen, wenn sie schon der Existenz eines so sinnengefährlichen Objekts wie einer Männerhose überhaupt Erwähnung tat, dafür das unschuldige ›Beinkleid‹ oder die eigens erfundene ausweichende Bezeichnung ›Die Unaussprechlichen‹ wählen**. Daß etwa ein paar junge Leute gleichen Standes, aber verschiedenen Geschlechtes, unbewacht einen Ausflug hätten unternehmen dürfen, war völlig undenkbar - oder stattdessen, der erste Gedanke war, es könnte dabei etwas ›passieren‹. Ein solches Zusammensein wurde höchstens erlaubt, wenn irgendwelche Aufsichtspersonen, Mütter oder Gouvernanten, die jungen Leute Schritt für Schritt begleiteten. Daß junge Mädchen auch im heißesten Sommer Tennis in fußfreien Kleidern oder gar mit nackten Armen, hätte als skandalös gegolten, und wenn eine wohlgesittete Frau in der Gesellschaft die Füße überschlug, empfand die ›Sitte‹ dies als grauenhaft anstößig, weil dadurch ihr Knöchel unter dem Kleidersaum entblößt werden könnte. Selbst den Elementen der Natur, selbst Sonne, Wasser und Luft, war es nicht gegönnt, die nackte Haut einer Frau zu berühren. Im freien Meer quälten sie sich mühsam vorwärts in schweren Kostümen, bekleidet vom Hals bis zur Ferse, in den Pensionaten und Klöstern mußten die jungen Mädchen, um zu vergessen, daß sie einen Körper besaßen, sogar ihr häusliches Bad in langen, weißen Hemden nehmen. Es ist durchaus keine Legende oder Übertreibung, **daß Frauen als alte Damen starben, von deren Körper außer dem Geburtshelfer, dem Gatten und Leichenwäscher niemand auch nur die Schulterlinie oder das Knie gesehen.**

It occurred to me that it may be a copyright breach to upload others' CC-BY-SA works (and by extension, derivative works) on youtube. It doesn't offer that as a license option (unless i missed something, i don't have first-hand experience); CC-BY (which it does) is obviously too lax and "standard license" fails to match SA requirement. I doubt mentioning CC-BY-SA in video description would be enough, because that does not change the fact that you're granting "standard license" to youtube which you don't have rights to (arising from CC-BY-SA itself; if the content is yours / you have rights to it, then there's no issue with double licensing)

comment.body: @Jayofthezero: i had setup my profile here on ZeroMe a few months ago (didn't use it much though or maybe even at all - can't remember exactly), then logged in tonight and it was still showing me my acc, but when i tried to post a message it didn't went through; then after page refresh my acc was gone and i had to 'register' again. (my ZeroId acc doesn't seem to be affected, only ZeroMe one)
@Jayofthezero: looks white to me too
@Jayofthezero: no, all i did was update ZeroNet by `git pull`

When i stumbled upon it, i was taken aback by their contributor copyright waver phrasing (it pretty clearly tells that contributors has less rights over software than bystanders). Chances are, i wouldn't go far with it anyway, though ideas seem pretty cool

@Krixano: i suppose it was meant to mean what you said. But i can't read it that way and more importantly i don't want to sign supposedly legally binding (how much binding it is is a different question which would also depend on jurisdiction) thing of which content i'm not so sure
@Tdd: i'm talking about PD itself (even if it's definitely not my favourite approach), i'm talking about copyright waiver: https://github.com/mawww/kakoune/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING

@Tdd: i don't see how it adds anything new to discussion, except for the fact that Kakoune author didn't invent that waiver. They don't explain why it should be worded as it is ("I dedicate **any** and **all** copyright interest in this software to the public domain)
most people have quite a mess in their head, sadly. so in a way, seeing such people on ZN could be seen as its success

@Tdd: where does it say anything about fork? "this software" does not legally mean "this repository" (if it even means anything specific, anyway); it pretty much says that you lose all present and future copyright rights ("all present and future rights to this software under copyright law."), which as far as i can see includes right to take that software and fork it
yeah, it seems to be a bit faster (possibly at the cost of processing power), but i wish they wouldn't force an interface change without user consent
@Tdd: i know i can fork and change license if it's public domain, however as far as i understand that waiver, anyone who signed it cannot

@Ekaterina: i don't really care about round tabs or color palette (since it still uses system colors); what i didn't like were toolbar changes, like those hideous (i know it's a matter of taste ^_^) empty spaces around addressbar, reload button move and lots of unnecessary buttons (which is essentially something so easy to preserve, if asked for). I realize there's a point in using "all-new" look by default, but really, adding one small button "make everything as close to previous settings as possible" wouldn't be so hard to do
@Krixano: i'm well aware of that. the point was that i don't like being forced to do something that software would obviously do faster
@Binchan: thx! I'll check out what tech git center (.md for site owner is enough for me) uses first and then see what to do with comments

@Binchan: yeah, well, i didn't have much luck finding such projects. most use md inside json or something like that. i hate js (and to a lesser degree webdev in general), so on one hand i'd like to reuse as much stuff as possible and on the other i don't know much about available options. apparently git center isn't of much help indeed, since it's too big to use for blog and otherwise i can just take any js markdown engine i guess (and still write some glue code, meh)
@Binchan: i've been using jekyll in clearnet, so i can surely just port that to 0, but.. as i mentioned, i don't like data duplication in repo and also would like to support newsfeed
@Binchan: i'm still hoping to get something proper with first-class 0net support. if that doesn't work out, i'll use static gen approach and see about notification options
@Binchan: it seems simple webdev isn't as unpleasant as i used to think, so going to go that road
@Ssdifnskdjfnsdjk: tried that (and also disabling owning site just in case), didn't get `content.json`. I wonder if i also accidentally pushed the change.
Huh, interestingly enough, i got it back by simply clicking "sign & push". Apparently it is stored somewhere else and not only in site directory?
@Ssdifnskdjfnsdjk: thx for suggestion, but it wouldn't be that important to bother with restoring, it's just a test site ;) but i got it working anyway
@Git Center: what about "includes"? i got it restored right as it was on signing. so perhaps this info is stored inside running instance?

@Binchan: RN demo & home page actually link to same page since i thought i'd capitalize on the few seeders that i had. I'm not actively promoting my home page (even in the way as i did with "empty page": posting on 0list, which seems to be more effective than posting on 0me) though since it's still not finished. Also it apparently weights more than standard 10MiB, i wonder if that's going to be a big issue.
I've been thinking about using VPS, but still too lazy to do that without enough content, but i guess i'll have to use it if i don't get enough peers after all measures taken.

@Binchan:
>On the other hand, the author tried to raise a new concept and named it "rationalization"

It's not a new concept. At the very least it was heavily popularized by psychoanalysis, but the idea itself is (probably much) older.

>but maybe, to some extent he was also rationalizing something..

That's kinda exactly the point. Many people who learn concept of rationalization start labeling it onto everyone whom they disagree with, but unable to find it in themselves, *even after trying to do so*.

Personally i only found it worthy of reposting since the author pretty openly admits that even that whole post might be rationalization. I'm planning to put a more formal logic that would allow to get out of this recursion in a more satisfactory way, though i suspect that might end up in rephrasing Kant.

>but sometimes we just need communication

That's the conclusion that led me to 0net ;)

@Binchan: my original thought was not about native language vs more popular language. I didn't say "care about language", but "care to understand language". And i only mentioned "native" because it seems to me that if person doesn't care to understand what is being said in language they have learned in childhood and spent most of their life thinking in, they are even less likely to care about understanding something said in other languages (and some people don't even know any other language).
More generally the problem is that many (maybe all to some degree, but the degree matters a lot in this case) people prefer (unconsciously, of course) to understand any external information (including text/speech in their native language, mentioned in original post) in a way that is most consistent with their expectations.

>Imo language is a communication tool but also a (culture) identity, and sometimes it's a secret/encryption

Yeah, but that identity appears to be largely illusionary. Different groups who speak supposedly single language might have the "tourist" level of mutual understanding.

@Binchan:

>We can also change to question to: Why do some people begin to care about understanding their native language?

Yeah, i suppose that question makes more scientific sense ;) Originally the context (in my head) was that even supposedly educated and smart people are in practice very often susceptible to selective perception of information, even on the level of not being careful about language parsing.

I know i shouldn't be really surprised by it and i can name many reasons that explain such behaviour. For one, it can be due to preferring fast reaction to multiple sources of information rather spending a lot of time to process one. For another, it can be due to a habit: by being exposed to a lot of low quality information (that does not need higher level processing) we risk dulling our ability to think.

But specifically the reason for my "surprise" was that even when people are being repeatedly exposed to the facts of miscommunication, they are not very likely to reflect on it and start listening others and expressing themselves more carefully.

>People don't learn a native language by learning grammar or language theory

Yeah, and sadly formal grammar education in school usually misses most of the audience. Learning second language is usually more useful in that regard because it leads to at least some comparison and thus better understanding even of the first one.

>I agree that identity isn't a good word, as it sometimes isolates a group and raises racism. Maybe familiarity, feeling at home, consensus are some better words.

My point about identity being illusionary was not about the word being appropriate. Rather, that the feeling of being similar due to speaking same language is largely an illusion.

Admittedly, sometimes language and cultural tradition go hand in hand and not very separated, but then it is more correct to say that language is a part of cultural identity, but it does not define it (i.e. you may speak the language but feel alienated from the rest of culture, even if there is single culture associated with language).

I think we can draw a fancy programmer parallel here. There's a saying "libs are languages": choice of library/framework quite often means more than language. Somewhat similar is with human languages: direction of thought, common themes, education and worldview often contribute more to productivity of communication than sharing native language.

>That's also something I'm concerning about. Because some children of my relatives here now speak more national language taught in school than native language learnt from the beginning. That's unavoidable I guess, because most of their time is now spent and exposed to the national language, and because they live in a more (inter)nationlized region.

Yeah, that's quite common and to some degree unavoidable. But personally i don't see anything *inherently* bad in it. I'd be quite happy if everybody would switch to a single logical constructed language as first lang or at least would be able to communicate in english.

I do like language diversity from aesthetical point of view, even if i don't spend a lot of time on systematic language learning these days. But from aesthetical PoV thousands of slightly differing languages might not be optimal.

But it seems to me that attaching inherent ethical value to diversity is a dangerous path (less dangerous than attaching ethical value to unification, though). It might be calculated as useful from evolutionary point of view, but such calculations can never be perfect.

That said, in reality such processes might happen in a bad way. As far as i understand, children bilingualism is more likely to cause issues than benefits with overall low level of education.

@Binchan:

>but I also feel your answers missed the keyword "native", i.e. you are more answering "Why do some people begin to care about understanding language?"

Well, generally i think that distinguishing between native and non-native is secondary and so i'm more interested in generic. As for the question, i'm not really answering it anyway; rather i gave an explanation for why it doesn't happen.

Also, i just noticed that phrase "to understand language" can have two somewhat different emphasises. I originally meant it to mean "to be able to understand what is said in language", but the emphasis can also be placed on understanding language as a separate entity.

>For some culture the language may not define the identity, but for some culture it does. German and Germany is a good example I guess, though some Dutch seems to consider German as not a real language, from the popular "American first, the Netherlands second" video [IFS] [Youtube] (so it may be just a joke).

Do you use german as example of language that defines identity?

>Similarly once I saw someone complaint "the grammar of English is that English has no grammar".

That's a really weird claim, unless the context is something like "most english speakers are non-native and don't know its grammar".

>If an individual gets alienated, it has nothing to do with the language, and my previous view "a group with same/similar identity (language) have some consensus, can understand and accept each other more easily, and are more willing to talk to and help each other." is still proper I guess.

If a language is only spoken by a tight culturally similar group, it may make sense for that language. But for a language spoken by hundred thousands or millions? It's hard to imagine such a group being all that homogeneous.

I would however agree that many people would "accept each other more easily, and are more willing to talk to and help each other" on the basis of using the same language. But when confronted with someone with different views, they can happily apply ["no true scotsman"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_true_Scotsman) argument or any other fallacy or cognitive bias to avoid actually accepting and understanding.

This is why i call the consensus and identity illusionary. It often works for people who are similar, but breaks when differently enough people confront each other.

>I guess the Japanese example I mentioned in previous post is still a counterpoint to this view.

>counterpoint

Hmm, did you mean "counterargument"? (Supposedly) more common musical meaning of word "counterpoint" seems to be only tangentially related.

>I prefer an idea that capable individuals learn more languages and bridge different culture (or creating a high quality translation machine), instead of all people in the world can communicate each other with the same language.

The problem with that is that it directs efforts of so-called "capable individuals" into learning languages instead of doing something else. But i'm not really interested in persuading anybody in that view.

>For the trend of decentralization (if it's not an illusion), I think we are favoring diversity than unification.

Well, decentralization isn't end value as well. Usually it's considered good for the sake of freedom and/or for the sake of instrumental advantages (such as better resource usage for torrents). Now, as for language diversity, i don't see how it can increase freedom. And instrumental advantages are always relative, not absolute (and we may not assess them correctly).

@Binchan:

>so a consensus can also apply to all human, like peace, empathy, fairness

Heh, i wish such consensus would be more widespread.

Although inspecting it more carefully, i should note that consenting to fairness is not a very meaningful one, since different people have widely different understanding of what is fair.

But i suppose that's a bit off-topic.

>Then that language is probably a macrolanguage instead of a single language

Ok, i suppose that's true.

>in WordNet "counterpoint" as a noun only means "a musical form involving the simultaneous sound of two or more melodies ", but in Oxford Dictonary it has three meanings, and one is "(written) a pleasing or interesting contrast"

[Wiktionary](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/counterpoint) also gives "An opposite point" definition.

>Yep, it's not for increasing freedom, imo diverisity is for more differences, more different kinds of things, more things that I still don't understand, and more possiblility.

Would it be better if everyone would speak their own unique language?

Would it be better if there would be millions of languages spoken in the world?

Would it be better if there would be hundreds of languages spoken in the world?

It's a scale of possibilities. I don't think i can persuade people who are not close to my opinion that it would be better if there would be a single common language, but it seems to me that arguing in favour of strictly keeping current balance is a very week position.

Looking from another angle: diversity in one area may take away resources from another. For example, consider how much resources is put into translation. Are you sure those can't be put to a better use that would create more possibility?

Natural sciences, social sciences, arts all create more possibilities and things you still don't understand and probably won't ever have time to consume. Even understanding each other while speaking supposedly single (macro)language proves to be a hard task. Every person can be viewed as unique regardless of language.

@Toootoo: interesting how word "native" seems to be dominating that sentence. I did not mean it in the way you interpret; i'm concerned about miscommunication that sometimes arises from people being inattentive to what they hear or read, *even* (but not limited to) in their native language.

@Binchan:

>still learning English is hard for many people in many regions, learning a language takes a lot of time

Yeah, sadly english has a lot of issues (irregular spelling is perhaps a big one for new learners). I wish some better language would become ubiquitous, perhaps a carefully created conlang (i find it unlikely to find natlang without irregularities).

>English isn't a good language for precise writing, if you agree..

I think it's slightly better than average, due to having a rich "extended" grammar that is however rarely used in many areas and can be misunderstood by those unfamiliar with it. That said, i suppose any language with philosophy and science tradition would have that.

In the end, i can't objectively compare english to other natlangs. One thing i do really like about it as a world's computer & network language is that it is pretty [analitic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytic_language) language (thus dumb string search is pretty reliable and generating messages is simple).

>a high quality translation machine is also ideal I suppose.

There are a lot of untranslatable ambiguities and nuances though.

>I think this problem should be solved by technology instead, aka translation machine or others.

I suspect that even the most sophisticated machine would not stop smaller languages being influenced by and even possibly merged into bigger ones. While it would solve the problem of extra work, it might also end up accelerating language extinction.

>What about replacing languages with species: would it be better if there are millions of species in the world? Or only hundreds of species?

Better for whom? What hundreds of species? Depending on that, it may be considered better or worse.

As for me, i don't like attempts to fit humanity into reflecting biological processes. Evolution and nature isn't all fluffy and nice. It's generally more cold and harsh. I think humans can do better. And if they can't, what's the point in their survival? Might as well die to make place for nature to spit out another bald monkeys after some millions of years.

>Arts has nothing to do with this topic I guess

Arts, just like sciences were an example of diversity and things to explore unrelated to language diversity.

>communicated arts with a common language.

Even if there would be one common language, it doesn't mean people won't be able to learn another or create their own (including conlanging as a form of art).

@Binchan:

>A single language itself also has a lot of ambiguities and nuances.

Exactly. But if you read/hear original speech, you have a chance at capturing such things. Even best translation rids you of that chance and the only way to get those nuances across would be to write a long footnote describe all possible meanings in the original.

>Why not try to save (keep) them from the beginning when it's possible?

I don't think you've answered why should we be trying to preserve them, rather than trying to reduce their amount or, on the contrary, invent new ones. For my "anti-conservative" mind possibility that exactly current situation is the best sounds very improbable and should be proved with something other than "lets save status quo".

>I don't think arts is unrelated to language diversity. Even some arts from the beginning are languages, like calligraphy.

You said that language diversity is good (perhaps among other things) because it creates interesting new things to explore. My point is that the efforts put into language diversity might as well be put into other diversities or just things to explore (where sciences, arts and math are just *examples*) and i don't see any way to evaluate what will result in a better diversity overall.

I won't argue about ecosystem analogy, because it is nothing more than an analogy and thus biased towards getting certain points across, but not proving them. In other words, it is good for illustrating position, but it isn't evidence that can be used as sound argument. If you believe otherwise, that would be deep enough difference to make further argument about languages useless.

@Binchan:

>My statement "translation isn't enough to understand and preserve them." is one of the answers

Why not create more languages?

>and your new statement "the only way to get those nuances across would be to write a long footnote describe all possible meanings in the original." also proves it I guess.

It could be taken as counter-argument to your position as well, because it means that as long as there are more languages than single human can learn, there will be misunderstanding and nuances will get lost.

Or it could be just taken as neutral statement, depending on other factors.

>But lost of diversity can become a different thing, it can mean the whole system is dying

>in the end would there be only one existing, then die of loneliness or mono.

I don't see enough evidence to suggest that current language extinction processes would ultimately lead to one language being left. At the point when there are only a handful of languages left it would be much easier to learn most of them, thus preventing further processes. Even if one language is dominating, there probably will always be people who would be interested in learning other (including dead ones; and note that internet languages will be much better preserved than ancient ones) languages for fun.

>They are not in conflict I suppose

Well, not in direct conflict, just sharing same resources.

>But without language diversity, no one could do the former any more. 

Language diversity already exists and it doesn't require us to actually speak them. Even if we imagine that suddenly everyone starts teaching their kids only english (or any other single language), we would still have large archives that no single human would be able to digest in a current lifetime.

>Yep, though imo proving, sound arguments may be necessary for debate, are not always necessary for discussion or understanding. And analogy can provide a wider/new vision for it, but this is a bit off-topic.

I think i understand your position well enough and the rest is indeed a debate. I could be mistaken (or it is possible that you don't understand my position) though. But it seems to me that we started going in circles.

First of all i should mention that i don't have enough technical understanding of all 0net features yet and my post was more about social aspect rather than technical.

It's good to hear about CORS and the fact that merger zites are being used in such a way.

>The other interesting idea that I think you may be thinking of is extracting out all the common parts of ZeroTalk, ZeroMedium, ZeroMe, ZeroVoat, etc. and putting all of that in one merger zite

Something like that, yeah. The main point is that the same posts can be made on different zites and people will see or not see them not based on their content preferences, but on their interface preferences.

I totally realize this isn't a trivial thing to do. Quite often it is easier to just write your own thing instead of spending great amount of time on negotiations and solving compatibility issues. I've done that myself and i guess that 0net might not have appeared at all without that. The reason i'm specifically talking about social zites (though it applies to content hosting zites to a lesser degree as well) is that their main goal isn't "make shiny interface with as much features as possible", but to be able to have meaningful conversations with interesting people (and secondary do it in a most convenient way).

I don't want to blame anybody for doing something wrong way. "If you want to do something right, do it yourself", but since i'm not doing it i wanted to at least share my perspective.

If i'd be motivated enough to develop a social zite, i'd start by trying to assemble as much active developers doing the same as i could and start discussing data structures, core engine features and migration possibilities. If developers would reach a reasonable consensus, technical issues like db migration can be solved, even if existing content will be migrated in an imperfect way. If i missed something and there's a place where developers discuss these things, i'd be happy to participate if not with code than at least with general ideas.

In conclusion: i think the issue is **more social than technical**.

@weakish: if the goal is to force learning all of the math, then maybe it's not a good way. However, why should that be a goal?

I don't say that learning category or set theory helps understanding polynomials. I rather think that feeding polynomials can make people start vomiting from math. Times table, quadratic equations, trigonometry, polynomials and many other math topics are a good way to force people away from math on one stage or another. Of course, they can be taught differently; explaining concepts usually doesn't hurt anybody. But forcing people to perform useless operations and memorize useless information just because "it will make you smarter" is killing interest.

Math is supposed to not rely on blind faith. Then why teaching it relies exactly on blind faith that your teacher knows what's good for you?

If you think category theory is hard to understand, i'll probably have to agree. In the end, i haven't actually learned it yet. But if one has to build enough concrete examples to understand it, then those examples might as well be something more exciting than abstract trigonometry and polynomials; for example, functional programming and cs in general, if learning other sciences doesn't sound like it would provide necessary abstractions. Learning programming is generally a very good way to make abstract math concepts concrete and interesting to wider audience: trigonometry suddenly becomes applicable in graphics, as do low-degree polynomials. Oh, and times table is still useless because computers can do a better job at it.

I guess there is any number of gui tools working with just html/css, but to make dynamic site you'll need to preserve some structure which might be harder to work with. Although it's mostly keeping certain class and id properties, so if you just move things around it should generally not break. But the style mostly depends on css, which you can even experiment with builtin browser tools (e.g. in [firefox](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Tools/Page_Inspector/UI_Tour)).

***

But whatever you use, for non-trivial tasks you'll likely have to have some level of understanding of how things work. The amount of things you can do with css alone is so big that presenting all of these options visually will be more confusing than with smart combination of visuals and text.

@Moor: well, one conclusion i've came to long time ago is that physicalism (materialism) cannot be correct (without losing its monistic character; substantial amount of people consider themselves materialists while admitting consciousness)
  
Time is fundamental and cannot have beginning or end (although heat death may look like an end, technically it isn't; big bang could have been start of a new "cycle" or birth of a new "bubble" or something like that) because that's how we think about change and causality. Other than that, there seem to be very little we can learn about it
  
Consciousness should also be fundamental, otherwise how can it appear? This makes solipsism quite convenient; though a big problem with solipsism is unexplained complexity of the world. But setting that aside, even if we for a second accept solipsism (or even plain old souls) and immortality, how long does one consciousness really last? Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be a good answer to that; anything besides "one moment" and "eternity" sounds arbitrary; and eternity is dubious when the only thing that "connects" consciousness of a person with, say, its 10 year ago self is memory, notoriously untrustworthy construct..
  
..at the end of the day, no one is going to answer simple question "why is it present now"

@Moor:

> physicalism may very well fall short but there is no contradiction in believing (inductively based on scientific research) that consciousness arises from physical interactions

From my pov, there's no way phenomenal (as opposed to "functional") consciousness can arise from something that isn't it. Scientific research is all good, but it is necessarily based on some assumptions about how the world and our ability to explore it work; so philosophy takes precedence. 
  
Besides, what's more important here, science cannot say anything about phenomenal consciousness: at best, every person has a "proof" about existence of their own consciousness, its universality is just extrapolation; so there's no way to apply proper scientific methods to it or meaningfully share results

> do you agree with Searle's Chinese room experiment? can you see the problem with it?

Not sure what does it mean to "agree with experiment"? You mean Searle's conclusion? In physicalist setting, it can be easily reapplied to prove that humans are analogous to weak AI as well ;) Which is i believe true in physicalist setting
  
If we ditch physicalism though, we're sorta out of luck in finding answers. Most reasonable to me seems that computers can't have consciousness, but i highly doubt that humans can, too

> our particular universe configuration

Oh, this needs terminology elaboration, i guess. If you're fan of talking about "multiple universes", that's fine too, but then what word should we designate to the meaning of "everything that exist"? Perhaps, "the world"?

Anyway, i was speaking of fundamentality of time (as well as consciousness) in the whole world, or to our thinking, which is essentially the same (since the only things we can reason about is product of our interpretation of raw input, which is just data, not "things in themselves"). I could imagine (though i find it highly unlikely) situation where *some notion* of time is no longer fundamental, e.g. some sorts of time travel; but to describe them, we'd need to add another notion of time, in which those travels actually happen

> as everything must happen eventually

While i disagree with that as i understand it, i should also point out that again, talking about "everything" is very prone to misunderstanding and confusion unless you specify what kind of "everything" you're talking about
